characters.name: Dr. Jonathan Swift
characters.description: The author of the essay, mentioned in the byline.

characters.name: Narrator
characters.description: The first-person speaker who proposes the satirical scheme for eating children to solve poverty.

characters.name: The Pretender
characters.description: Historical figure (likely James Francis Edward Stuart) whom some Irish leave to fight for in Spain, and later referenced as a threat.

characters.name: Principal gentleman in the county of Cavan
characters.description: A gentleman who informed the narrator about children's proficiency in thieving, protesting that few under six are skilled.

characters.name: American acquaintance
characters.description: A knowledgeable American in London who assured the narrator that a year-old child is delicious food and later that older boys' flesh is tough.

characters.name: Eminent French physician
characters.description: An author who noted that more children are born in Roman Catholic countries nine months after Lent due to fish diet.

characters.name: Very worthy person
characters.aliases: My friend, Excellent friend, Deserving patriot
characters.description: A patriotic friend who suggested extending the scheme to eat young lads and maidens as a substitute for venison.

characters.name: Psalmanaazor
characters.description: A man from Formosa who came to London and told the worthy person about selling executed bodies as delicacies in his country.

characters.name: The Emperor
characters.description: The ruler in Psalmanaazor's story, whom a girl attempted to poison.

characters.name: Prime minister of state
characters.description: A high official who bought the body of an executed girl in Psalmanaazor's account.

characters.name: Plump girl of fifteen
characters.description: A girl executed for attempting to poison the Emperor, whose body was sold as a delicacy in Psalmanaazor's story.

characters.name: The Narrator
characters.description: The speaker proposing a satirical solution to Ireland's poverty, claims no personal interest, has been offering ideas for years, has a wife and children but none young enough to benefit from the proposal.

characters.name: Narrator's Wife
characters.description: Mentioned as being past child-bearing age, part of the narrator's family.

characters.name: Narrator's Children
characters.description: The narrator's offspring, with the youngest being nine years old, too old to be involved in the proposal.

book_metadata.title: and for making them beneficial to the publick.
book_metadata.author: Dr. Jonathan Swift
